summary: This is an email chain from August 2020 regarding the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) preparing to provide electronic records from its investigation into the USAO-SDFL's handling of the Epstein matter to the USAO-SDNY Public Corruption Chief. It discusses logistics for transferring the records and notes the records were collected for an administrative investigation and may not be complete for criminal discovery.

persons.name: Chief, Public Corruption USAO-SDNY
persons.context: The email is addressed to this individual, who is the Chief of the Public Corruption unit at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, regarding the transfer of investigative records.

persons.name: Counsel, Office of Professional Responsibility
persons.context: The author of the initial email, a counsel at the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility, outlines the process for providing electronic records from OPR's investigation into the USAO-SDFL's handling of the Epstein matter.

connections.description: The OPR counsel is communicating with the SDNY Public Corruption Chief regarding the transfer of investigative records related to the Epstein matter.

events.title: OPR offers Epstein investigation records to SDNY
events.description: The Office of Professional Responsibility emails the USAO-SDNY Public Corruption Chief to offer electronic records from OPR's investigation into the USAO-SDFL's handling of the Epstein matter.

events.title: Forwarding of OPR materials email
events.description: The initial July 29 email regarding OPR's Epstein investigation records is forwarded to another recipient.

locations: U.S. Department of Justice, 950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Room 3266, Washington, D.C. 20530
keyFacts: The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) conducted an administrative investigation into the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida's (USAO-SDFL) handling of the Epstein matter.
OPR is prepared to provide its collected electronic records from that investigation to the Public Corruption unit of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY).
OPR provides a strong caveat that the records were acquired for its administrative investigation and 'cannot be represented to be complete for criminal discovery purposes.'
The correspondence discusses logistical methods for transferring the records, either via encrypted hard drive or through the JEFS system.
The email indicates hard copy files from the investigation exist but are a 'small quantity compared with the electronic files' and would require physical review.
